results.title: Jem Cohen: early works
results.brief_description: A rich and haunting collection of early works from an artist who paints with fragments of image and sound from New York street life. Dogs, passing cars, the homeless, drugged and alienated people drift through these works, in the rhythms of their own time. Simple mysteries are uncovered through a window, in half deserted streets, and in wind blown garbage. Voices become confessions, shadows become cinematic and we are absorbed and compiled into a world of wonder, in which people inevitably leave traces - and lists.

group_works.title: This is a history of New York

results.title: This is a history of New York
results.brief_description: ‘This is a History of New York’ chronicles the seven ages of mankind from Prehistory to the Space Age. In the Age of Hunters and Gatherers, stray dogs patrol the streets while the homeless forage for food. Later in the Medieval Period, crazed street preachers pace frantically before ominous gothic architecture. The richness of Cohen’s vision is found in this haunting imagery and the perception that the thriving city of New York is really the accumulation of humanity’s failures, as well as triumphs.

group_siblings.title: Just hold still. Parts one and two
group_siblings.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio

results.title: Just hold still. Parts one and two
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: In his New York City Landscape, Cohen finds inspiration in disturbance. Looking to life for rhythm and to architecture for state of mind, he locates simple mysteries. `Just Hold Still’ is comprised of an interconnected series of short works and collaborations that explore the grey area between documentary, narrative and experimental genres. Part One concerns a personal, poetic approach to narrative while Part Two involves hybridized use of verite footage and the confrontation of documentary concerns with the music video format. The work can be considered as a whole or each piece in the project can be viewed (and rented) as a separate entity.

results.title: Drink Deep
results.brief_description: Drink Deep is a lyrical vision of friendship, hidden secrets, and desires. Cohen uses several types of film image to add texture to the layered composition. Beautiful shades of grey, silver, black and blue echo the water, reminiscent of early photography and silverprints. Cohen says, “The piece was constructed primarily from footage I’d shot of skinnydippers at swimming holes in Georgia and rural Pennsylvania. It’s about water and memory and stories just submerged. It is also, in part, a response to thinking about censorship. I would say that Drink Deep is both unabashedly and deceptively romantic. Surface, flow, and undertow. What looks like paradise is always paradise lost.” Music composed by Stephen Vitiello and performed with Gabriel Cohen and Mary Wooten.

results.title: Black Hole Radio
results.brief_description:
Over the past 20 years, filmmaker Jem Cohen has assembled a massive visual archive of Super 8 and 16mm by filming everyday images and experiences as he negotiates his way through the spaces of New York City. Filled with enigmatic glimpses, gestures and images seeming to come from half-remembered dreams, memories and snatches of conversations, this archive contains hints for unearthing the many secrets of contemporary metropolitan life.
In the mid 1990s Cohen encountered a series of advertisements for a New York City ‘Phone Confession Line’.To call in and confess was free; to listen cost money. Cohen acquired recordings of these taped confessions of murderous thoughts, desire and treachery, and used them to form the audio heartbeat of his video installation ‘Black Hole Radio’. Accompanied by ghostly Super 8 images filmed by the artist during his nocturnal wanderings, the installation reveals the anonymous lives and restless spirits that haunt the phonelines, televisions and sleepless nights of the city.
For this version of the installation, ACMI has worked with the artist to create a small confessional cell where images shimmer like paranoid hallucinations while disturbing whispers hang in mid-air, semi-publicly. The elusive images that linger on the edge of visual perception provide the evidence of Cohen’s investigation into the small confessed ‘crimes’: loving the wrong man, harbouring hatred or greed. Visitors leave ‘Black Hole Radio’ feeling the way they do when a shameful memory wakes them in the dead of night. Inside Cohen’s confessional, it is understood that it is both a privilege and a curse: to live as social beings and to know that isolation and forgetting can’t conceal the troubled heart of the city.

results.title: Play It Again II: Games Collection
results.brief_description:
The Play It Again II project aims to document, preserve, and create an accessible and playable history of Australasian videogames and videogame culture from the 1990’s.

This collection comprises physical games and hardware donated to ACMI for the project and as well as game emulation files created by ACMI or harvested from external web repositories.

The project is being undertaken by ACMI in partnership with Swinburne University, RMIT, AARNet, UNESCO PERSIST and OpenSLX GmbHt.
This project is supported by the Australian Government through the Australian Research Council Linkage Program. Play It Again II is a continuation of Play It Again I, which focused on the preservation of Australasian videogames from the 1980’s.

production_dates.notes: Games in this Collection date from the 1990s. The ARC research project "Play It Again" (II) will be completed in 2022.

results.title: Flight of the Amazon Queen [DOS]
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD jewel case with insert, manual, registration card and installation guide in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Flight of the Amazon Queen is a point and click adventure where you play Joe King as he uses his plane, the Amazon Queen, to fly famous actress Faye Russell to a film shoot. When the plane crash lands in a remote jungle, and he must use his wits to battle his way out of the dangers he faces.

As with many point and click adventures, a set of icons at the bottom of the screen allows the player to interact with other characters or the environment. The game has since been ported to smartphones, with the addition of improved graphics, full voice acting, multi-language support and a play through of the interactive interview mini-game with audio commentary by John Passfield, one of the game’s designers.

constellations_primary.name: Gender bending larrikins
constellations_primary.description: Australia has a long history with gender creativity and drag culture, both on screen and on stage.

results.title: Shadowrun [SNES]
results.creator_credit: Data East USA and Beam Software
results.material_description: Cartidge videogame. Cartridge, reference sheet and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
The world of Shadowrun is defined by the Awakening, where magic has been re-discovered, and human beings have accepted the existence of those they thought to be fantasy creatures. Mega-corporations and cyberworlds now share the world with elves and Native American shamans.

The player is Jake Armitage, a seemingly ordinary data courier who is assassinated by a hit squad in the year 2050 in Seattle, Washington. A mysterious figure rushes to Jake and cast a spell on him and he wakes up in the morgue with complete memory loss. Jake must now begin to unravel the mystery of his death and miraculous resurrection.

The game is a skill-based role playing game (RPG) with action-oriented combat. The player can use firearms and learn magic spells, primarily with defensive and support capabilities. The game was a critical success, winning a number of industry awards, but was a commercial failure nevertheless. It was retrospectively acclaimed by several publications as an “ahead of its time” milestone in the history of the role-playing genre for the consoles and credited for having pioneered film noir style in video games.
